author: HCAndersen
text: Now listen!

author: HCAndersen
text: In the country, close by the high road, stood a farmhouse; perhaps you have passed by and seen it yourself.

author: HCAndersen
text: There was a little flower garden with painted wooden palings in front of it; close by was a ditch, on its fresh green bank grew a little daisy; the sun shone as warmly and brightly upon it as on the magnificent garden flowers, and therefore it thrived well.

author: HCAndersen
text: One morning it had quite opened, and its little snow-white petals stood round the yellow centre, like the rays of the sun.

author: HCAndersen
text: It did not mind that nobody saw it in the grass, and that it was a poor despised flower; on the contrary, it was quite happy, and turned towards the sun, looking upward and listening to the song of the lark high up in the air.

author: HCAndersen
text: The little daisy was as happy as if the day had been a great holiday, but it was only Monday.

author: HCAndersen
text: All the children were at school, and while they were sitting on the forms and learning their lessons, it sat on its thin green stalk and learnt from the sun and from its surroundings how kind God is, and it rejoiced that the song of the little lark expressed so sweetly and distinctly its own feelings.

author: HCAndersen
text: With a sort of reverence the daisy looked up to the bird that could fly and sing, but it did not feel envious.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I can see and hear," it thought; "the sun shines upon me, and the forest kisses me.

author: HCAndersen
text: How rich I am!"

author: HCAndersen
text: In the garden close by grew many large and magnificent flowers, and, strange to say, the less fragrance they had the haughtier and prouder they were.

author: HCAndersen
text: The peonies puffed themselves up in order to be larger than the roses, but size is not everything!

author: HCAndersen
text: The tulips had the finest colours, and they knew it well, too, for they were standing bolt upright like candles, that one might see them the better.

author: HCAndersen
text: In their pride they did not see the little daisy, which looked over to them and thought, "How rich and beautiful they are!

author: HCAndersen
text: I am sure the pretty bird will fly down and call upon them.

author: HCAndersen
text: Thank God, that I stand so near and can at least see all the splendour."

author: HCAndersen
text: And while the daisy was still thinking, the lark came flying down, crying "Tweet," but not to the peonies and tulips- no, into the grass to the poor daisy.

author: HCAndersen
text: Its joy was so great that it did not know what to think.

author: HCAndersen
text: The little bird hopped round it and sang, "How beautifully soft the grass is, and what a lovely little flower with its golden heart and silver dress is growing here."

author: HCAndersen
text: The yellow centre in the daisy did indeed look like gold, while the little petals shone as brightly as silver.

author: HCAndersen
text: How happy the daisy was!

author: HCAndersen
text: No one has the least idea.

author: HCAndersen
text: The bird kissed it with its beak, sang to it, and then rose again up to the blue sky.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was certainly more than a quarter of an hour before the daisy recovered its senses.

author: HCAndersen
text: Half ashamed, yet glad at heart, it looked over to the other flowers in the garden; surely they had witnessed its pleasure and the honour that had been done to it; they understood its joy.

author: HCAndersen
text: But the tulips stood more stiffly than ever, their faces were pointed and red, because they were vexed.

author: HCAndersen
text: The peonies were sulky; it was well that they could not speak, otherwise they would have given the daisy a good lecture.

author: HCAndersen
text: The little flower could very well see that they were ill at ease, and pitied them sincerely.

author: HCAndersen
text: Shortly after this a girl came into the garden, with a large sharp knife.

author: HCAndersen
text: She went to the tulips and began cutting them off, one after another.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Ugh!" sighed the daisy, "that is terrible; now they are done for."

author: HCAndersen
text: The girl carried the tulips away.

author: HCAndersen
text: The daisy was glad that it was outside, and only a small flower- it felt very grateful.

author: HCAndersen
text: At sunset it folded its petals, and fell asleep, and dreamt all night of the sun and the little bird.

author: HCAndersen
text: On the following morning, when the flower once more stretched forth its tender petals, like little arms, towards the air and light, the daisy recognised the bird's voice, but what it sang sounded so sad.

author: HCAndersen
text: Indeed the poor bird had good reason to be sad, for it had been caught and put into a cage close by the open window.

author: HCAndersen
text: It sang of the happy days when it could merrily fly about, of fresh green corn in the fields, and of the time when it could soar almost up to the clouds.

author: HCAndersen
text: The poor lark was most unhappy as a prisoner in a cage.

author: HCAndersen
text: The little daisy would have liked so much to help it, but what could be done?

author: HCAndersen
text: Indeed, that was very difficult for such a small flower to find out.

author: HCAndersen
text: It entirely forgot how beautiful everything around it was, how warmly the sun was shining, and how splendidly white its own petals were.

author: HCAndersen
text: It could only think of the poor captive bird, for which it could do nothing.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then two little boys came out of the garden; one of them had a large sharp knife, like that with which the girl had cut the tulips.

author: HCAndersen
text: They came straight towards the little daisy, which could not understand what they wanted.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Here is a fine piece of turf for the lark," said one of the boys, and began to cut out a square round the daisy, so that it remained in the centre of the grass.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Pluck the flower off" said the other boy, and the daisy trembled for fear, for to be pulled off meant death to it; and it wished so much to live, as it was to go with the square of turf into the poor captive lark's cage.

author: HCAndersen
text: "No let it stay," said the other boy, "it looks so pretty".

author: HCAndersen
text: And so it stayed, and was brought into the lark's cage.

author: HCAndersen
text: The poor bird was lamenting its lost liberty, and beating its wings against the wires; and the little daisy could not speak or utter a consoling word, much as it would have liked to do so.

author: HCAndersen
text: So the forenoon passed.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I have no water," said the captive lark, "they have all gone out, and forgotten to give me anything to drink.

author: HCAndersen
text: My throat is dry and burning.

author: HCAndersen
text: I feel as if I had fire and ice within me, and the air is so oppressive.

author: HCAndersen
text: Alas!

author: HCAndersen
text: I must die, and part with the warm sunshine, the fresh green meadows, and all the beauty that God has created."

author: HCAndersen
text: And it thrust its beak into the piece of grass, to refresh itself a little.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then it noticed the little daisy, and nodded to it, and kissed it with its beak and said: "You must also fade in here, poor little flower.

author: HCAndersen
text: You and the piece of grass are all they have given me in exchange for the whole world, which I enjoyed outside.

author: HCAndersen
text: Each little blade of grass shall be a green tree for me, each of your white petals a fragrant flower.

author: HCAndersen
text: Alas! you only remind me of what I have lost."

author: HCAndersen
text: "I wish I could console the poor lark," thought the daisy.

author: HCAndersen
text: It could not move one of its leaves, but the fragrance of its delicate petals streamed forth, and was much stronger than such flowers usually have: the bird noticed it, although it was dying with thirst, and in its pain tore up the green blades of grass, but did not touch the flower.

author: HCAndersen
text: The evening came, and nobody appeared to bring the poor bird a drop of water; it opened its beautiful wings, and fluttered about in its anguish; a faint and mournful "Tweet, tweet," was all it could utter, then it bent its little head towards the flower, and its heart broke for want and longing.

author: HCAndersen
text: The flower could not, as on the previous evening, fold up its petals and sleep; it dropped sorrowfully.

author: HCAndersen
text: The boys only came the next morning; when they saw the dead bird, they began to cry bitterly, dug a nice grave for it, and adorned it with flowers.

author: HCAndersen
text: The bird's body was placed in a pretty red box; they wished to bury it with royal honours.

author: HCAndersen
text: While it was alive and sang they forgot it, and let it suffer want in the cage; now, they cried over it and covered it with flowers.

author: HCAndersen
text: The piece of turf, with the little daisy in it, was thrown out on the dusty highway.

author: HCAndersen
text: Nobody thought of the flower which had felt so much for the bird and had so greatly desired to comfort it.
